translated: How is the establishment of one's own nature possible when the arrangement of origination, dissolution, bondage, liberation, etc. is seen? Fearing this, it is said that since this [arrangement] is caused by one's own ignorance and imagination, the establishment of one's own nature alone, which is free from any counter-correlate, is unrestricted. It is said that there is no cessation, etc. Cessation is dissolution. Origination is birth. The bound one is the transmigrator. The knower who is the means of attaining liberation. The seeker of liberation, who desires to be liberated from one's own ignorance and its effects, is the one who seeks liberation. The liberated one is the one whose bonds of transmigration are severed. Since such imaginations arise from the existence of something other than one's own self, the general [entity] that is other than one's own self is unreal like the horn of a rabbit, and therefore origination, dissolution, etc. that are other than one's own self are of the nature of absolute non-existence, which is free from any counter-correlate. In this regard, the terms such as māyā, ignorance, knowledge, the universe, the internal organ, etc. are of the nature of absolute non-existence in relation to Brahman, as stated in the Parmākṣara [Upaniṣad]. Therefore, cessation, etc. do not exist in one's own nature alone. This alone is the ultimate reality. Hence, the establishment of Brahman alone, which is free from any counter-correlate, is unrestricted.

translated: Similarly, one with the vision of one's own ignorance sees the difference of the many selves that conform to limiting adjuncts. When the limiting adjuncts are removed, one does not see that difference. He says by the word etc. The word-maya is the cause of the proliferation of the meaning of the word. Or it is the maya that is more skillful in creating what was not created before, which has the nature of mere word without meaning, which is of the nature of verbal expression. The creature covered by that, like a creature covered by darkness, does not go to the lotus, the supreme purifier, the self. When the darkness of one's own ignorance is removed by one's own knowledge, like removing darkness by a lamp etc., and by the word ca (and), when the impression of that is destroyed, one sees the oneness of the pratyagatma (the self that faces the inner reality) and the paramatma (the supreme self). Or, the one with ignorance, being covered by the word-maya, like a creature covered by darkness in a lotus, does not go to the knowledge of the oneness of all beings with the Brahman that faces the inner reality.
